bioghist.p: Dorothy Nelkin (1933-2003) was an historian of ethics in science and technology. She was a professor of sociology at New York University from 1988 until her death. Prior to NYU, she was a professor of sociology at Cornell University. Nelkin earned her bachelorâ€™s degree at Cornell University. She was a prolific author who wrote or co-wrote 26 books. Her works include Controversy: Politics of Technical Decisions, The DNA Mystique: The Gene as a Cultural Icon, and The Molecular Gaze: Art in the Genetic Age. Her research interests included science and culture, sociology of science, bioethics, politics of biotechnology, and science and the law.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Dorothy Nelkin. Materials include: drafts and reprints of Nelkin's writings; clippings and photocopies of background articles; published reports; trial transcripts; papers by Nelkin's students; and books and journals in which Nelkin's writings appeared. There is some correspondence within Nelkin's subject and project files, as well as a small batch of correspondence related to her employment at NYU. Subjects in the collection include the Human Genome Diversity Project, tissue banking, DNA fingerprinting, genetic engineering and cloning, AIDS, and organ transplantation.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
